subject: statistics
title: Types of Data
contentHtml:
In statistics, data can be categorized into four main types: categorical, ordinal, interval, and ratio scales.

Categorical data represents categories or labels, such as colors (red, green, blue) or eye colors (blue, brown, hazel). Ordinal data has a natural order or ranking, like exam scores (A-F) or job titles (intern, manager, CEO).

Interval and ratio scales have meaningful differences between consecutive values. Examples include temperatures in Celsius or Fahrenheit, and measurements of physical quantities.
intuition: Understanding the type of data is crucial for proper analysis and interpretation.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, knowing the type of data helps determine the appropriate algorithms to use.
For instance, using a clustering algorithm on categorical data might not be effective.
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize the type of data can lead to incorrect conclusions or misinterpretation.

subject: statistics
title: Types of Data
contentHtml:
Data can be categorized into four main types: categorical, ordinal, interval, and ratio scales.

A categorical scale represents data that is qualitative, such as colors or species. Values are distinct categories rather than numerical values.

An ordinal scale represents ordered data where the difference between consecutive values has meaning, but not necessarily equal intervals. Examples include survey responses (e.g., 1-5) or rankings.

An interval scale represents data with equal intervals between consecutive values, but no absolute zero point. Examples include temperatures in Celsius or Fahrenheit.

A ratio scale represents data with both equal intervals and an absolute zero point. Examples include lengths measured in meters or weights measured in kilograms.
intuition: Understanding the type of data is crucial for selecting appropriate statistical methods, visualizations, and machine learning algorithms.
realWorldApplications: In natural language processing, understanding the categorical nature of text data can inform topic modeling and sentiment analysis
